Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Examining the Effectiveness of New Zealand's Water Quality Policy in Enabling Farm-Scale Behavior Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Runoff of nitrogen and phosphorus from agricultural lands is impacting water quality in rivers and lakes across the globe. Social and political factors have proven to be barriers to effective management of these nutrients. The Lake Taupo and Lake Rotorua watersheds in New Zealand are implementing innovative water quality policies which regulate nutrient use at the farm scale. The success of this policy is dependent on the extent to which these policies change farmer behavior. To understand how these water quality policies are affecting behavior, the researcher will conduct a policy analysis and in-depth interviews with farmers in each region. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Suzie Greenhalgh, a noted expert on water quality policy, at Landcare Research in Auckland, New Zealand. This project will contribute to a greater understanding of which attributes of water quality policy promote social, ecological and economic well-being with the goal of improving policy design.

This policy analysis will examine the effectiveness of New Zealand's governance approach to managing agricultural nonpoint source pollution. Importantly, Lake Taupo and Lake Rotorua?s water quality regimes are rare examples of water quality policies that require farmers to achieve a mandated nutrient leaching rate from their farms. Methodologically, the research will employ key informant and stakeholder interviews, and will focus on the farmer as the unit of analysis. The analysis will use Elinor Ostro's Social Ecological Systems Framework and Design Principles to examine how the policies in place enable, influence or enforce behavior change. This research will improve understanding of the efficacy of alternative approaches to water quality policy design and implementation. This is of importance to the numerous regions globally approaching ecological limits in water quality and searching for means to regulate resource use.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Countries across the globe, including New Zealand (NZ) and the United States (USA), are struggling with the question of how to best manage diffuse water quality pollution to protect and improve water quality. While much is known about the physical process of this diffuse pollution, less is known about the social, economic, and political dynamics that contribute to the persistence and expansion of the problem. Two contrasting approaches to water quality policy can be seen in the Lake Taupo and Rotorou Lakes Basins, NZ and Lake Champlain Basin, Vermont (VT), USA. These approaches represent opposite ends of the policy spectrum in that one focuses on regulating modelled diffuse pollution from farm systems (NZ) and the other focuses on regulating the use of specific farm management practices (USA). The research undertaken for this East Asian Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) in New Zealand contributes to an improved understanding of the effectiveness of specific applied policy approaches through comparing, assessing and evaluating the NZ policies. This research was conducted in collaboration with Dr. Suzie Greenhalgh, a noted expert on water quality policy, at Landcare Research in Auckland, NZ. The EAPSI research will ultimately contribute to a broader research study through which the NZ and VT policies will be evaluated and compared.  

As a part of the EAPSI NZ, 36 in-depth interviews were completed with farmers and other stakeholders in the Lake Taupo and Lake Rotorua watersheds in June-July 2016. In total, 22 farmers were interviewed and 14 stakeholders, including regional council policy makers, representatives of interest groups and consultants who participated in the policy process. Farmers interviewed represent the diversity of farm systems in both watersheds, including dairy, beef, sheep and others. In the farmer interviews, farmers reported details of their farm systems, procedures for managing nutrients that contribute to diffuse water quality pollution, any recent changes to procedures, reasons for making changes, and overall perception of water quality policy, the policy process and policy outcomes. Stakeholder interviews focused on attributes of the water quality policy, the policy process, and policy outcomes. All interviews are being analyzed using content analysis methods to evaluate overall trends in farm management, the policy impact on farmer behavior, and other social, economic and political drivers of farmer behavior in each watershed. Following completion of interviews with Vermont farmers in March-June 2017, all data will be combined to compare and evaluate across NZ and USA water quality policy. Outcomes of this research, including academic papers, a policy brief, and a public presentation, will contribute to a greater understanding of which attributes of water quality policy promote social, ecological and economic well-being with the goal of improving policy design.
